Notes: Pre 1950s óstán/ósdán  teach/tigh ósta/ósda in Irish

Pre-1950s bliadhain in Irish. The form bliadhna (bliana today) is used as a special plural form following numerals; the regular plural is blianta). Some eastern Scottish Gaelic dialects use the form bliadhn[8].
Also réidió and rèidio in spoken Irish and Scottish Gaelic
Pre-1950s genitive ríogh and dative rígh in Irish
In Irish  eaglais is a Roman Catholic house of worship; a Protestant house of worship is called a teampall (temple). As Gaeilge 'séipéal' is also used as it can mean chapel as well.

In Classical Irish the forms were "i"  "a"  "in"  "an" – "i/in" when the following sound was slender  and "a/an" when the following sound was broad. In both Irish and Scottish  in the spoken language  the four forms of "i"  "a"  "in"  "an" still exist.
In Irish  aire for a government minister
Bruíon (formerly bruighean) in Irish means "fighting"  "quarrelling." Cainnt in Scottish Gaelic is used as a noun only  meaning "speech " except in Arran where it is also a verb[9]

column5: A number of words are used in both languages for "ocean" and "sea"  such as aigéan/aigeun  an fharraige. Caladh or cala (also in the compound "calafort" < "cala-phort") are commonly used in Irish for "harbour".

Breatain (Britain) is the same in both. The Scottish Gaelic equivalent for Wales is A' Chuimrigh  a Gaelicisation of an Anglicisation of the Welsh Cymru. The Irish for Brittany is An Bhriotáin from Latin "Britannia".
Siubhail means "walk" or "stroll" in Scottish Gaelic  but is also a euphemism for death
